reviewText: This film is an excellent mix of drama and comedy, loaded with pathos. Gregory Peck looks and acts like a wooden board (doen't he always?), but in this particlualr role his normally drab persona actually fits. While admittedly funny, Tony Curtis goes a bit over the top by portraying Corporal Liebowitz in a stereotypical Jewish vein. Eddie Albert is excellent. But the actor who shines brightest is Bobby Darin, who was nominated for an Academy Award for his role in this film. As shellshocked flier Jim Thompkins, Darin peforms as admirably as he did in "Pressure Point." He was a great talent, alleged histrionics and all. Try picturing the inanimate Peck or the Brooklynese  Curtis (who, in dramtic roles never came off as believable) playing Thompkins in the sodium pentathol scene and you'll quickly realize how versatile Darin was as an actor and entertainer.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A precursor of sorts to "M*A*S*H" in that it takes a somewhat critical view of the military establishment, "Captain Newman  M.D." is an intelligent comedy-drama with Gregory Peck as a military  psychiatrist beset by a variety of troubled patients, most notably a  traumatized corporal played by singer Bobby Darin who received a  well-deserved best supporting actor Oscar nomination for his splendid work  here.  Peck is good, too, bringing his trademark blend of stoic pride and  quiet compassion to the title role.  The comedy, most of it provided by  conman Tony Curtis, doesn't always blend smoothly with the drama, but the  cast keeps this generally absorbing film on a mostly steady track  throughout.

reviewText: I confess that I hadn't heard of this movie until recently (it seems to have slipped under the radar for many others as well), but I think this is one of the most fascinating films to deal with the subject of post-traumatic stress disorder in the armed forces. Certainly there had been attempts before CAPTAIN NEWMAN, M.D. (like "The Best Years of Our Lives") but I doubt that 1963-era audiences were fully prepared for the emotional impact of NEWMAN.Gregory Peck stars in the title role, the head of the Psychiatric Ward at Colfax Army Barracks, Arizona, in the waning months of WW2. Newman has a tough assignment in "curing" his patients within a set amount of time before they are then shipped back into active service. Of course there's an obligatory love interest for Newman (Angie Dickinson is Lt. Francie Corum, his vivacious offsider), and Tony Curtis plays for laughs as resident prankster Cpl. Jake Leibowitz.The film's highpoint is arguably Bobby Darin, playing against type as a shellshocked young pilot; a performance that netted him an Academy Award nomination. Look out for Jane Withers, sorely under-used as one of the Colfax nurses. Robert Duvall, Eddie Albert and Bethel Leslie co-star.This DVD release is the same as the one previously featured inThe Gregory Peck Film Collection (To Kill a Mockingbird | Cape Fear | Arabesque | Mirage | Captain Newman, M.D. | The World in His Arms).

reviewText: I admire what this movie is trying to do, show some damage war does yet keep it entertaining.  It's like what Mash was trying to do and it uses the same solution (mix comedic scenes with dramatic scenes) though not as successfully as Mash.  The comedic scenes are more jarring than in Mash; it doesn't meld as well.  For example they go from a scene with an anquished screaming mental patient to the hospital ward playing hide the salami...literally.The most noteworthy thing is the oscar nominated performance of Bobby Darin.  He really was good though not as good as his performance in Pressure Point.  And his big flak juice scene is a tad over the top.  He should have been directed to scale it back just a bit.  Another scene of his that doesn't quite ring true is when he's sobbing in the psychiatrist's office but can't squeeze out a tear.  He's dry as the Las Vegas desert.  He's much better in his other scenes, esp the ones where he plays a drunk.  Darin always played drunks well (in spite of never touching a drop in real life) as can be seen in the Stars Bar segment of his saloon act.Overall worth seeing esp by Darin fans who are curious about his oscar nominated role, and who own a fast forward button.
summary: Admirable movie, sort of like pre-Mash Mash, with good Darin performance
Title: N/A

reviewText: A strange movie but a good viewing experience nonetheless; in turns hysterically funny and incredibly depressing.  What was disconcerting was sometimes it was funny and sad at the same time, which left me feeling unduly manipulated and I don't know why.  The material was strong enough on its own without having to resort to cheap tactics to lead us to the correct response.  I'm perfectly capable of judging a situation for what it is without having to be hit over the head with a sledgehammer; sometimes writers forget this.Otherwise, the strong points far outweigh the bad.  All of the actors were agreeable (although I don't understand why Bobby Darin was singled out for a best supporting actor Oscar nomination over everyone else).  Tony Curtis easily stole the movie from everyone (proving just how one should procure a Christmas tree).  The movie was also Oscar nominated for Best Sound and Screenwriting Adaptation (it took 3 screenwriters to adapt the story!).I'm glad I got the chance to watch it.
summary: "He'll make a good orderly.  He understands suffering."

reviewerName: F. J. Harvey "Cricket ,country music and a go...
reviewText: Captain Newman M.D fluctuates between scenes of strong deeply etched drama and somewhat contrived and misfiring comedy ,the latter scenes  strive to be heartfelt and touching but succeed only in being mawkish and sentimental .Thus a potentially provocative and edgy drama is vitiated by the interpolation of scenes which drag proceedings down to the level of a routine feel good movie.The title character -played by Gregory Peck -is chief of a neuro -psychiatric ward on a US military hospital site in the States in 1944.He is at odds with the brass who dislike his strongly patient centred approach as it means he is often reluctant to return patients to active duty at the rate his superiors would like.The movie centres on a trio of cases .One involves a decorated corporal(Bobby Darin-overacting wildly)who erroneously feels a coward for having deserted a comrade in a burning plane ;another is a colonel (Eddie Albert--in a compelling performance )who has gone berserk with guilt for having sent men on missions from which they never returned ),and an upper crust officer (Robert Duvall )catatonic with guilt for haaving hidden away in a cellar in ...occupied Europe rather thaan try to escape.The cases are resolved with varying degrees of success .In between these cases Newman dallies with an attractive nurse -the always enticing Angie Dickinson -and observes the wheeling and dealing of his scheming but good hearted orderly ,played by Tony Curtis.Peck is admirable and his peformance is shrewdly underplayed -his acting is quiet but expressive and he is well supported by Curtis in what is essentially a secondary role as the comic relief.Often moving ,this is in some respects an early version of MASH as a service drama with comedic undertones .Marked own a point for not concentrating more on drama and interpolating crowd pleasing comedy elements that for me just do not jell.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Whenever people talk about the great Gregory Peck's best films, for some reason this one is forgotten.  It has been one of my favorites since seeing it with my father in the movies in 1963.  It was previously released only as part of a Gregory Peck collection put out a couple of years ago.  It has now been released on its own.  I highly recommend it.This comedy/drama features Peck as a compassionate Army Psychiatrist at a Psychiatric hospital in the U.S. durring WWII.  Tony Curtis (in a role similar to his previous role in "Operation Petticoat,") plays Leibowitz, the con-man orderly shanghaied into Peck's unit.  (My father's favorite part of this film is when Curtis teaches a group of Italian POWs, led by the terrific character actor Vito Scotti,to perform an American Indian number during the film's concluding Christmas Pageant and they wind up singing and dancing the Jewish song "Havah Nagilah."  My father laughed so hard that he almost fell out of his seat and he went home telling everybody he ran across to see this film.)  Angie Dickinson is wonderful as the head nurse and Peck's romantic interest.  And Bobby Darin in his supporting-actor nominated performance plays "Little Jim," an Army Air Force machinegunner with a major psychiatric problem.  (For some reason, Curtis in his autobiography says that he thought Darin was terrible in the role and couldn't understand his academy award nomination.)The four leads are great and the supporting cast is incredible.  Among those co-starring are Eddie Albert (terrific,) Robert Duvall, the always great James Gregory, Larry Storch, Jane Withers, Dick Sargent, Bethel Leslie and others.I don't know why more people don't remember this wonderful film, it is a wonderful combination of hilarious comedy and deadly serious drama.  The DVD unfortunately features no extras.  I would have loved a retrospective with the surviving cast members.As stated previously, I highly recommend it.

reviewText: For those who are Veterans and dependents of military, here is a movie ahead of its time, andhas an invaluable manner of speaking to some problems today - our military personnel - whetherReserve, Active Duty, Retired or Veteran:  The problems are PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Syndromealso known as "Battle Fatigue"), "Battle Neurosis" and "Shell Shock."  For those of us who arenot licensed Mental Health Experts, the DVD movie contents have actual examples which help theaverage person understand the differences of military combat problems.  For example, Captain Newmandealt with a Sailor who was stressed out and wanted to protect his Brother Frank.  The Sailor didnot have a Brother Frank, but had a good friend blown away next to him in combat.  That is a goodexample of PTSD; The Captain helped the Sailor realize he was worn out from constant combat duty,there was nothing wrong with the Sailor who needed rest and assurance he could not save his friend.The Sailor was able to return to duty.  Another good example, was a Marine with genuine combatneurosis, a mental health defect which existed before his enlistment in the military; the Captaincould not help the Marine; the Marine managed to sneak outside the mental health ward, climbed tothe top platform of a water tower, and jumped to his suicidal death?! True, every case is uniquebut the value of "Captain Neuman, M.D.," is a very positive perspective to understand combatrelated problems for military personnel and their dependents as well as the community, without beingburdened with medical-technical terms.  This is a DVD you can view and do not need a dictionaryand medical reference books to understand the contents!

reviewText: Although Gregory Peck might have been a bit more human - who could be in control of his emotions like that? - his performance was excellent. I had mostly known Bobby Darin as a singer, so his role in this came as a surprise. He was superb! This movie conveys the horrors of war without having to show any battle scenes; it's all there in the minds of the men who came back and couldn't leave the war behind them. This movie is relevant today, as much as, or more than, ever. Tony Curtis adds the humor that is needed to lighten the subject and to help to show how laughter can help to heal.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie's setting is late WWII. It was a time when the effects of war on the human psyche were not fully appreciated. What now are recognized as mental disturbances were commonly dismissed as cowardice (recall the incidents of General Patton slapping two hospitalized soldiers for being "yellow bellies"). In time, the notion of "shell shock" and "combat fatigue" gave way to the modern concept of post-traumatic stress syndrome.The movie itself focuses on men who have been deeply scarred by seeing their colleagues die, and especially by being unable to do anything about it. One man copes by disassociation. He develops multiple personalities, one of whom is a Mr. Future that remembers nothing of the past. Another patient can recount his horrors only when sedated by truth serum (sodium pentathol). Still another patient is consistently catatonic.The outcomes of the patients vary. One gets better and is released back into combat. Another one commits suicide. Still another is visited by his wife in hopes that this will improve his mental condition.There is a place for levity in this film. A Christmas Party is set up, in large part by a Jewish officer. It features a makeshift Christmas tree, and a rousing performance, by Italian POWs, of a Jewish song. Of course, familiar Christmas carols are also sung. Santa Claus also makes his appearance.
summary: Dealing With Combat-Related Mental and Psychological Disturbances

reviewText: Universal Pictures  presents "CAPTAIN NEWMAN M.D." (1963) (126 min/Color) -- Starring: Gregory Peck, Tony Curtis, Angie Dickinson, Eddie Albert, Bobby Darin & Robert DuvallDirected by David MillerCaptain Josiah J. Newman, M.D. (Gregory Peck) is the head of a psych-unit at a Southwestern army base during the waning days of World War II. Newman is a patriarchal protector to his patients, preferring to keep him in his ward, rather than return them to certain death on the battlefield. The matriarchal figure of the ward is Lieutenant Grace Blodgett (Jane Withers), but Newman is more interested in his assistant Lieutenant Francie Corum (Angie Dickinson), with whom he is having an affair.Further help is provided by human nature expert, Corp. Jackson Laibowitz (Tony Curtis), the orderly. Three patients: Colonel Bliss (Eddie Albert) is suffering from a guilt complex from all the men he has sent to death; Corporal Tompkins (Bobby Darin), although decorated for bravery in combat, calls himself a coward for failing to save his pal from a burning plane; and Captain Winston (Robert Duvall) is guilt-ridden and has lapsed into catatonia because he had hidden for over a year in the basement of a building in Germany.Darin's performance was outstanding, allowing himself to become the character he was betraying.Oscar Nominations for Best Supporting Actor (Bobby Darin), Best Sound & Best ScreenplayBIOS:1. reviewText: Unlike others who describe it as "mawkish," I thought it well-played and compelling.Bobby Darin's part has been described as overplayed, and it may have been.  If so, It did not detract, and in fact extra histrionics was called for by the part he played, to make the story believable.This was a film about a psychiatric ward in a Western desert (Arizona) military hospital during the Second World War, filled with Army Air Corps veterans and their problems, mostly caused by the stress of combat in both the European and Pacific theaters.Captain Newman (Gregory Peck), was the hero.  Angie Dickinson and Tony Curtis did a superb job supporting, and Eddie Albert--an actual WWII combat hero-- and others did a great job as well.  This one came out in 1963, and was greeted with critical acclaim at the time of its release.One flaw--not a serious one--in Albert's part (Colonel Bliss) is the suggestion that he would receive a medical discharge.  A bird colonel, almost certainly a professional, in the real world would have received a physical evaluation board's recommendation, and been granted temporary disability retirement, followed five years later by re-evaluation and permanent retirement.  I did.  The services treat their people better than simply dumping them.  The explanation involving such a development would, no doubt, have been too time-consuming for mere movie entertainment.Also, from the script it would seem that they relied on sodium pentothal ("flak juice") a lot in those days.  It was, of course, used as a "truth serum" (and still is), but is also a widely used general anaesthetic in major surgery.  I wonder whether it was as widely used as described, in psychiatric cases.  I often wonder how accurate such details are in describing the reality of history.  No doubt much would depend upon the dosage.This was an entertaining film, and no doubt conveyed some truth.Joseph (Joe) Pierreauthor of Handguns and Freedom...their care and maintenanceand other books

reviewText: David Miller, a talented hack who started out "directing" shorts for MGM, those documentary-style featurettes that would run for six or seven minutes and you now see them presented as "One Reel Wonders" on Turner Classic Movies.  Though Miller showcased Robert Taylor in BILLY THE KID and the Duke in FLYING TIGERS, by the 1950s he was primarily thought of as a women's director, a sub-par George Cukor, who reined in Joan Crawford in two of her more restrained vehicles, SUDDEN FEAR and THE STORY OF ESTHER COSTELLO, but couldn't do much for Ginger Rogers in TWIST OF FATE nor Susan Hayward in BACK STREET (the remake).Therefore it isn't especially surprising that, although it's pretty much an all guys picture, the role played by Angie Dickinson emerges as the most interesting part of all.  She's the observer, the onlooker, whose vantage point into a chaotic military psych hospital we see all the action through.  She's by turns bewildered, upset, angry, and finally supportive of Peck's attempts to change the future for a handful of his men.  Angie's career had its ups and downs, but I don't think she ever had as sympathetic a director as David Miller, nor a part that better fleshed out her curious blend of modernity, toughness and compassion.

reviewText: Captain Newman, MD is a very good award winning movie from theearly 60's. If you can forget the searing visuals ofBand of Brothers and put yourself back in a more innocenttime, then the drama presented by great performances byBobby Darrin and Eddie Albert packs a wallop. Possiblythe best performance of either of their careers.Gregory Peck establishes a sound foundationthat allows them to soar. As always,Robert Duvall provides a solidly enjoyableperformance.  Sadly, the writing and low production valuesremind me that this was the time when movies were losingmoney and audience to Ed Sullivan.  But, if you makeallowance for that, it can be a great experience.

reviewText: All-Star Cast in a film I have not seen in my entire life? How did that NOT happen?I completely Loved this body of work. The acting was top notch and I was disappointed to see it didn't get a single Oscar. Only 3 nominations. Clearly Bobby Darin's performance SHOULD have gotten him an Academy Award. Eddie Albert was superb! Robert Duball's part was very limited. Gregory Peck, Tony Curtis, and Angie Dickinson was Superb as well!!I liked the writing! Dealing with subject matter probably left alone for a long long time. Clearly this was fledgling stages of treating PTSD. I believe the subject matter that touches on the futility of getting these guys well enough to get them back into combat only to see them killed later. Hawkeye Pierce deals with that on an episode of MASH where he loses it and is complaining that the patch up the wounded only to ship them back to the front lines where they might get killed or wounded again and brought back. In my words, this is the irony that produces the words, WAR is HELL!Great Movie and I hightl recommend this!!

reviewText: I like Gregory Peck, and he does a good job in portraying his character and making him believable.  There are a number of other big names from Hollywood throughout this movie, and I was always surprised when another one of them popped up.  A young Robert Duvall has a small part that he plays well, but for my money, Eddie Albert was the real scene stealer in this movie.  I was surprised at how captivating and intriguing his character was.  Angie Dickinson was young and beautiful and her smile brightened up every scene she was in.  The movie is a bit long for my taste, otherwise I would have given it a 5 star rating.  However, it is one I'm proud to own and will no doubt watch again.

reviewText: From my first run viewing in a theater through subsequent viewings on commercial TV (and hating every commercial break), then on VHS and now DVD, "Captain Newman, MD" has been one of my all time favorite movies. When someone invented the word "dramedy" it perfectly described the film. There is drama, comedy, pathos and tragedy. Set during WW 2 in a military psychiatric hospital, Peck's performance as Newman is as well-balanced as a high wire act. He is center ring around which all the others, dependent on his wisdom, strength and professionalism swirl. Adding their own unique layers to the mix are Tony Curtis at his most comic character inventiveness, Bobby Darin showing his acting chops as the deeply troubled G.I. Little Jim; Eddie Albert in a brilliant portrayal of a high ranking officer who finally sent one too many men to their deaths, and an equally brilliant yet totally opposite portrayal by a young Robert Duvall of a silent, withdrawn and catatonic officer. Sexy Angie Dickinson is a nurse and Newman's love interest. I recommend this movie to anyone who has a heart and an interest in beautifully realized stores that hit all the marks by actors in their prime.

reviewText: The movie takes place in a Army/Air Force Mental hospital with all sorts of patients and even crazier orderies.  The Doctor "Captain Newman, goes into a new place and treats the patients much differently than what the norm was.  Results are great humor, sad stories, great acting by great actors just it's not the type of film to get awards because in some ways it was "anti-establishment" and this was well before other films like "One flew over the cuckoo's nest."

reviewText: and yet, this SUPERB film isn't on DVD! ARGH!!!!Dr. Josiah Newman (Gregory Peck) runs the psychiatric unit of a U.S. Military Hospital during WWII. Short of help, Newman coerces newly arrived neurotic orderly Jackson Leibowitz (Tony Curtis) to work in his ward. Leibowitz's scheming & humor quickly turns life inside the ward upside down. Newman, while amused, tries to maintain a semblance of order. Newman's other recruit to the ward is nurse Lt. Francie Corum (Angie Dickinson). Corum is at first shocked by what she sees in the ward, but admires the compassionate & effective way in which Newman deals with each of his patients. Together Newman & Corum help a variety of patients with war related psychological traumas, while they themselves struggle with the dilema of healing these soldiers so they can be sent back into battle to face possible death.At the time of the writing of this review, you can only get this on VHS (if you're lucky), and catch it on AMC. I really wish this was on DVD. I'd buy it in a HEARTBEAT.
